title: Web3 Gaming: What’s Next? — with Sebastien Borget from Proof of Talk Paris

rawLines.text: live. No.
Welcome back to Proof of Talk right here
in Paris. My name is Gareth Jeninson.
I'm the head of multimedia here at

more alive than you ever saw before. The
only thing though is like it's also more
fragmented than it was a few years back.
when like there was only one main

more spent, more time by user into our

So, we get good signals that actually
games uh are here and growing like the

into large success at speed we've never

Yeah. Um for those of you listening,
please do drop your questions for
Sebastian. If you have some burning

burning questions about web 3 gaming,

abraction. You don't want to build your
like peer-to-peer matchmaking system.
And so once now like you have like more

sequence or even metamas improve largely
their UX. Once we have now system where
like um users can actually put their
user generated content on a marketplace
available and sell across and like
avatar system that's uh and marketplace
that can be sold across many games with
player zero protocol or wagering system
where you can challenge one of your
friend for very small bet and like
whoever win into a skill-based game.
That's Olympics. I think it's it's
definitely valuable. So then like game
developers can actually focus on the one

infrastructure should actually be like
all the team which are better at this
that provide them. Very few are the team

How do you keep people playing? Uh how

Because I still think that no web 3 game

nobody in web free gaming has actually

what Amster combat has demonstrated is

essentially uh hello to bootstrap like

fantastic. Now, um tokens are great to

but game developers also have to focus
on like something we it's I would like
to push as an industry metric, which is

for every single token that's being

reward or airdrop. How much of that

we've been able to increase by 4x

through NFTs that have real utility.
battle pass, avatars and equipment that
actually improve your skill through game
play and I think it should be just the

think about like there's one side like

uh I think that's a pretty good

before the main net which are on the

because most of the team like they are a

haven't come back from a traditional

been approaching it was maybe a little
bit too much skewed toward like
blockchain as a feature and the core

like the complexity of like user
education toward like how it all the
effort it takes to like build uh and to
bring an account with a wallet, credit,
fill it with like the gas token and so
on. Mhm. And all of that when you
compare to platform like the app store,
Google Play Store, Switch or Epic Store,
all of that difficulty is actually
removed because the platform already
have like the user data on them. So for
them is like three clicks away from the
download toward the game. Yeah, we're
getting much better UX. We're getting
better gameplay. We're understanding
better the the tokconomics and gameplay
mechanics. So, I'm confident that there
will be a moment like a Fortnite or
Roblox on chain will appear. I don't
know if will we will still call it pure
web free gaming. That's an abradation of
like web 2.5 free. Yeah, but we are not
that far from that moment. I've got
another good question from the from the
live stream here. What percentage of
sandbox users actually come to play and
not just buy land? I think it's a pretty
good question. Well, it's a great
question actually. The the the fact is
like most of like land owners are just
like holders and believe in the vision
of the platform but not creators or
players. I think roughly 30% of our land
owners 27,000 of them are just playing
or creating but all the rest they are
sitting on their land. So the actually I
will reverse the question like how do we
keep engaging and attracting the other
70%. On a good side I think like the
success of sandbox is like we have
different audiences. Some are like just
players enjoying the season starting to
spend more than they actually earn. Back
to that return on reward spend. We have
creators who are like the most of course
creative engaged passion audience who
are ready to buy land who purchase asset
and to build and enjoy participating in
our builder challenge and game jam. And
we have that whole subset of like land
owners, avata holders, 57,000 of them.
And sand holders, more than 370,000 on
decentralized exchange and maybe more on
centralized exchange. That we need to
keep building a platform that deliver
value to every single of those

based on the launch we're planning this

and maybe some of the other games out

like you were mentioning telegram game
lampic abstra combat and a few other of
course we're looking at that uh of the

Nexon is a great title to look into as
well that's that's inspiring for the

and and really be perceived by everyone

coding and uh will be the next phase of
like the no code movement and will

something that empower every creator to

date we have 28 uh SIP sandbox

Live. No.

Welcome back to Proof of Talk right here in Paris. My name is Gareth Jeninson. I'm the head of multimedia here at COINTELEGRAPH, and we are live streaming from the event. It's been a fantastic day so far. We've heard from the likes of Barry Silbert and a number of high-profile individuals from the cryptocurrency space and really just enjoying this venue. I'm joined by a man I know quite well, Sebastien Borget from the Sandbox. A lot of our viewers out there will know Sebastian, and we're going to be talking about Web3 Gaming, because it's been a topic I haven't been covering a lot in the last year or two. I mean, my job has changed a little bit, so I'm doing a little less writing these days. But it does feel like a lot of attention moved away from Web3 Gaming. As someone who's built one of the most popular Web3 games out there, what's your general take on Web3 games at the moment? Has it been in a lull? How do you get out of this? Well, it's always good to see you here, Garrett. And well, let me put it straight, like Web3 Gaming is kicking and alive, and like it's been more alive than you ever saw before. The only thing though is like it's also more fragmented than it was a few years back, when like there was only one main blockchain, essentially Ethereum, and all the projects were on Ethereum. So nowadays, like most of the Web3 games, like successful ones, let's talk about like Off the Grid, Pixels, or like the new Maple Story, they are on different chains, like on one side you have like a whole Telegram tone ecosystem which bosters a lot of games and gamers, you have on Avalanche, you have Ronin, you still have Ethereum and Polygon, but they take a smaller portion of the attention. And so, you have all those pools of silos of gamers and successful games, but they are not interconnected. There is no like liquidity across those. The tokens don't easily flow across those, and so, you have actually an impression that Web3 Gaming is smaller, but I think like overall there's probably 300 million wallets that are connected across all those different games. At Sandbox, we're also noticing with the different seasons we've launched, like more engagement, more spent, more time by users into our metaverse season and experiences. Yeah. So, we get good signals that actually games are here and growing, like the right games with the right fun and engagement formula can actually kick off into large success at speed we've never seen before. Okay. But if it's hard to get the big picture if you're not if you're just in one of those ecosystems or you don't really oversee it from the top. Yeah. Um, for those of you listening, please do drop your questions for Sebastian. If you have some burning questions about the Sandbox, some burning questions about Web3 Gaming, where the trends are going, what chain you should be building on, what's good, what's bad, he's the man who knows. So please drop the questions, and as this conversation goes on, I'll pose some of these questions to Sebastian. My next question to you is, um, how much is developing infrastructure playing a role in Web3 games? Um, I know the guys from Olympics. I've spoken to them quite a lot. Pudgy Penguins are now building on their infrastructure, and it's making it a lot more accessible for people that are not blockchain native to build games and then plug in the blockchain infrastructure and and be able to tokenize that in certain ways. So you and I can play a Web3 game, let's say, Wordle on Telegram, and I challenge you, and I put down two USDT, and if you can solve the word faster than me, you get the money. Um, I think that's a fantastic use case for, you know, sort of a peer-to-peer, um, like more engaging, more socially interactive approach to gaming, and now the infrastructure is there. Have you seen a large change in the last year? Um, we can talk about Ton and what happened there a little bit as we go along, but how do you feel about the infrastructure at the moment? Well, I do absolutely believe that like game developers are usually choosing an ecosystem or a chain for like the audience that it has, like the user, and also like the whole developer toolkit that's available. Like you absolutely do not want as a game developer to reinvent the wheel every time. You do not want to build your own marketplace. You don't want to build your own wallet or cut abstraction. You don't want to build your like peer-to-peer matchmaking system. And so once now like you have like more developed solutions with wallets like Sequence or even Metamask improve largely their UX. Once we have now systems where like, um, users can actually put their user-generated content on a marketplace available and sell across, and like avatar systems that's and marketplace that can be sold across many games with Player Zero protocol or wagering systems where you can challenge one of your friends for a very small bet and like whoever wins into a skill-based game. That's Olympics. I think it's it's definitely valuable. So then like game developers can actually focus on the one thing they should be the best at, which is like making fun games, and all the rest, the tool set, like the tech, the infrastructure should actually be like all the teams which are better at this that provide them. Very few are the teams that will have be good at focusing on both, and if as a game company, as a startup, you have to prioritize on your go-to-market, let's start with the game rather than like the tech. I remember this time last year at Proof of Talk, um, Hamster Combat had just come out, and it was like, I think it was a month into the launch. They already had like a 100 million players on on the tapping, uh, you know, the the tapping game. It really fizzled out after the token generation event. I think a lot of interest just waned. But the way that they approached doing it made me pretty excited about like Web3 games again and you know, like blockchain-based games, and it it didn't have a native token then when it launched the token, I think that they failed in many aspects to do something that that would keep people playing. Sandbox has been around for a long time. How do you keep people playing? Uh, how do you bring the monetization element into what you're doing? And like how difficult is it to solve that problem? Because I still think that no Web3 game has completely figured it out. Well, nobody in Web3 Gaming has actually figured out like the successful recipe that anyone else can copycat. Like we're such into an early stage of experimentation and sometimes failure, but there is a learning curve, and like definitely we are seeing progress. Like what Hamster Combat has demonstrated is like basically a good network here, like the Telegram network can essentially uh, hello to bootstrap like the user acquisition to grow the community and to grow games to like levels of audiences we've never seen before. Combat is so simple in the gameplay, so accessible thanks to Telegram network and the wallet. It it was fantastic. Now, um, tokens are great to provide like value toward the community, but game developers also have to focus on like something we it's I would like to push as an industry metric, which is called like the return on reward spend for every single token that's being distributed to a user in form of claim, reward, or airdrop. How much of that token is going to go back into the game economy? And to make it come back into the game economy, you actually have to build great features, fun gameplay that people want to spend time to keep enjoying. That's we've been doing at Sandbox. So typically, you were asking me like how do we keep Sandbox entertaining? Like we launch once a year, but now we accelerate to three times a year a new season that lasts a few weeks, and people enter by like just creating an avatar. Everything is for free. I think there's a very simple answer, but at the same time it does make you wonder like why isn't there a Web3 game that everyone is just playing and they can actually earn some money from playing it? And all of that when you compare to platforms like the App Store, Google Play Store, Switch, or Epic Store, all of that difficulty is actually removed because the platform already have like the user data on them.
